messalla: <entryFree id="n28872" type="main" key="Messalla"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Messalla</orth> (less correctly <orth extent="full" lang="la">Messāla</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n28872.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman surname in the</hi> gens Valeria: <cit><quote lang="la">Corvinus primus Messanam vicit, et pri mus ex familiā Valeriorum, urbis captae in se translato nomine, Messana appellatus est: paulatimque vulgo permutante litteras, Messalla dictus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Vit. Beat. 13" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Vit. Beat. 13</bibl></cit>. The most celebrated is the orator M. Valerius Messalla Corvinus, in the time of Cicero and Augustus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:15:17:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 15, 17, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">16, 16</bibl>, A, 5; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:4:1:1" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 4, 1, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:371" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 371</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Contr. 2:12:8" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Contr. 2, 12, 8</bibl>.—In <number>plur.</number>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:4:16:43" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 4, 16, 43</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
messana: <entryFree id="n28873" type="main" key="Messa_na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Messāna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*messh/nh</foreign>. <sense id="n28873.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A Sicilian city, situated on the strait between Italy and Sicily</hi>, the mod. <hi rend="ital">Messina</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:8:section=17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 8, § 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:7:16" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 7, 16</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">incumbens Messana freto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:14:194" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 14, 194</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28873.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Another name for</hi> Messene, <hi rend="ital">in the Peloponnesus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,003:1:422" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Ach. 1, 422</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Messānĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., Messanic</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">moenia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 17</bibl></cit> Merkel.</sense></entryFree>
messanius: <entryFree id="n28874" type="main" key="Messa_ni^us1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Messānĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. Messenius.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n28875" type="main" key="Messa_ni^us2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Messānĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. Messana <sense id="n28875.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
messapia: <entryFree id="n28876" type="main" key="Messa_pi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Messāpĭa</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Mesāpĭa</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n28876.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the old name of a part of Lower Italy</hi> (Apulia and Calabria): Messapia Apulia a Messapo rege appellata, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=125" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 125</bibl> Müll.; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:99" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 11, 16, § 99</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Messāpĭus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Mesāp-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Messapia, Messapian, Apulian, Calabrian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">arva,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:513" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 513</bibl></cit>.—In <number>plur.</number>, as <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Messāpii</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Mesāp-</orth>), <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the Messapians</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 24</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
messapus: <entryFree id="n28877" type="main" key="Messa_pus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Messāpus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Mesāp-</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n28877.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a mythic prince in Messapia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:691" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 691</bibl>; cf. Paul. ex Fest. s. v. Messapia, p. 125 Müll.</sense></entryFree>
messeis: <entryFree id="n28878" type="main" key="Messe_is"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Messēis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*messhi/s</foreign>, <sense id="n28878.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a fountain in Thessaly</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 8, 15, § 30</bibl>.—As <hi rend="ital">adj., of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to the fountain Messēis</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Messeides undae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:4:374" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 4, 374</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
messene: <entryFree id="n28879" type="main" key="Messe_ne_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Messēnē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Messēna</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Messāna</orth>),<cb n="MESS" />  <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*messh/nh</foreign>, <sense id="n28879.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the capital of Messenia, in the Peloponnesus, on the river Pamisos</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Maura-Matia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:3:4" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 3, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 5, 7, § 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,015:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Ep. 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,016:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pel. 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:36:31:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 36, 31, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:32:21:23" default="NO" valid="yes">32, 21, 23</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:417" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 417</bibl>; cf. Messana, II.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Messēnĭus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Messā-nĭus</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">*messh/nios</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">Messeni an</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Messenia arva (al. Messania),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:679" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 679</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28879.1" n="II" level="1"> <pos>Subst.</pos> </sense><sense id="n28879.2" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Messēnia</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the country around Messene</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 5, 7, § 15</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n28879.3" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Messēnĭi</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the Messenians</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:36:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 36, 31</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
messia: <entryFree id="n28880" type="main" key="Messi^a1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Messĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>messio</etym>, <sense id="n28880.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the goddess of reaping</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Spect. 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n28881" type="main" key="Messi^a2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Messĭa Silva</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n28881.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a wooded hill on the right bank of the Tiber, south-west of Veii</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:33:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 33, 9</bibl> Hertz (Weissenb. Maesia), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:225" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 58, 83, § 225</bibl> Jan. (al. Mesia).</sense></entryFree>
messias: <entryFree id="n28882" type="main" key="Messi_as"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Messīas</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>Heb., the Anointed, Gr. <foreign lang="greek">*xristo/s</foreign></etym>, <sense id="n28882.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the Messiah, Christ</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Johan. 4, 25</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 4, 7</bibl>, and in the eccl. fathers saepiss.</sense></entryFree>
messio: <entryFree id="n28883" type="main" key="messi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">messĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>2. meto</etym>, <sense id="n28883.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a reaping</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">frumenti tria genera sunt messionis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:50:1" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 50, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Job, 29, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,049:51:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Jer. 51, 33</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 2</bibl> Sam. 21, 9.</sense></entryFree>
messis: <entryFree id="n28884" type="main" key="messis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">messis</orth>, <itype>is</itype> (<sense id="n28884.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">acc. sing.</hi> messim, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 134</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 1, 3, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:5:2:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 5, 2, 53</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:2:6" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 2, 6</bibl>; v. Neue, Formenl. 1, p. 200), <gen>f.</gen> (<hi rend="ital">masc.</hi>: non magno messe, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 213 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>) [id.], <hi rend="ital">a reaping and ingathering of the fruits of the earth, a harvest</hi> (class.). </sense><sense id="n28884.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">messis proprio nomine dicitur in iis, quae metuntur, maxime in frumento,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:50:1" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 50, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:9:5" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 9, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:8" default="NO">8, 3, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:58:249" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 58, 249</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:219 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 219 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">seges matura messi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">messem hordaceam facere, aream in messem creta praeparare,</quote> <trans><tr>to get in the harvest</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:295" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 30, 71, § 295</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">messe amissā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:54:section=125" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 54, § 125</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">messis feria, Cod. 3, 10, 2.—Of the gathering of honey,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:231" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 231</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28884.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, concr., <hi rend="ital">harvest.</hi> </sense><sense id="n28884.3" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The harvested crops, the harvest</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">illius immensae ruperunt horrea messes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 49</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 314</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:8:99" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> E. 8, 99</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:24:7:6" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 24, 7, 6</bibl>: Cilicum et Arabum, <hi rend="ital">the harvest of the Arabians</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">saffron and frankincense</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:3:3:34" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 3, 3, 34</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">bellatura,</quote> <trans><tr>the men that sprang from the dragon's teeth sown by Cadmus</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> Laud. Stil. 1, 321</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n28884.4" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The crops that are to be harvested, the standing crops, the harvest</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">messium incensores, vel vinearum olivarumve,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul.</author> Sent. 5, 20, 5</bibl></cit>: messes suas urere, prov., like vineta sua caedere, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to destroy one's own work</hi> (e. g. one's own pupils), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:2:98" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 2, 98</bibl>: adhuc tua messis in herba est, <hi rend="ital">your wheat is still in the blade</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">you are premature in your expectations</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:17:263" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 17, 263</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n28884.5" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The time of harvest, harvest-time</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si frigus erit, si messis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:5:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 5, 70</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg> transf. for <hi rend="ital">a year</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sexagesima messis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:4:79:1" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 4, 79, 1</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n28884.6" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">pro benefactis mali messem metere,</quote> <trans><tr>to receive evil for good, to reap ingratitude</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:5:2:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 5, 2, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">uberem messem mali,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 3, 2, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(morum malorum) metere messem maxumam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 1, 1, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si attigeris ostium, jam tibi hercle in ore fiet messis mergis pugneis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:4:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 3, 4, 58</bibl></cit>: Sullani temporis messem, <hi rend="ital">the harvest of the time of Sylla</hi>, when so many were killed, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,047:6:2:46" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Par. 6, 2, 46</bibl>; (in eccl. Lat.) <hi rend="ital">the time for winning souls to the truth</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">transiit messis, finita est aestas, et nos salvati non sumus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,049:8:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Jer. 8, 20</bibl></cit>.—Of <hi rend="ital">the persons to be gathered into the church</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">messis quidem multa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:10:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Luc. 10, 2</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Johan. 4, 35</bibl>. —Of <hi rend="ital">the end of the world</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sinite utraque crescere usque ad messem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:13:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 13, 30</bibl></cit>; cf. v. 39.</sense></entryFree>
messor: <entryFree id="n28885" type="main" key="messor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">messor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n28885.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a reaper</hi> (class.). </sense><sense id="n28885.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:12:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 12, 46</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">durus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:643" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 643</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">feniseca,</quote> <trans><tr>a mower</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:2:18" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 2, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dura messorum ilia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:3:4" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 3, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">parce messoribus illis qui saturant urbem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:8:117" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 8, 117</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28885.2" n="B" level="2"> Personified: <cit><quote lang="la">deus Messor,</quote> <trans><tr>the god of the harvest</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. G. 1, 21</bibl></cit>.—* </sense><sense id="n28885.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">reaper of men</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sator scelerum et messor maxume,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 3, 5, 3</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:13:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 13, 30</bibl> and 39.</sense></entryFree>
messorius: <entryFree id="n28886" type="main" key="messo_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">messōrĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>messor</etym>, <sense id="n28886.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to a reaper</hi> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">messoria corbis,</quote> <trans><tr>a reaper's basket</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:38:82" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 38, 82</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">falces,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 1, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">opera,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:2:13:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 2, 13, 2</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
messuarius: <entryFree id="n28887" type="main" key="messu^a_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">messŭārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n28887.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj</hi> [messura], for messorius, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to reapers</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">corbis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> Verg. E. 8, 82</bibl></cit>. <pb n="1139" /> <cb n="META" /></sense></entryFree>
messura: <entryFree id="n28888" type="main" key="messu_ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">messūra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>2. meto</etym>, <sense id="n28888.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a reaping</hi> (post-class.), Primas. ap. Gall. c. 6: <cit><quote lang="la">messuram dicimus, non metitionem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 374</bibl></cit> P. (dub.)</sense></entryFree>
messus: <entryFree id="n28889" type="main" key="messus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">messus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, v. 2. meto.</entryFree>
mestria: <entryFree id="n28890" type="gloss" key="Mestria"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mestria</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n28890.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman surname</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Fabr.</author> p. 621, 181</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
mestrianus: <entryFree id="n28891" type="gloss" key="Mestria_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mestriānus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n28891.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman surname</hi>, Inscr. Malvas. Marm. Felsin. p. 253.</sense></entryFree>
met: <entryFree id="n28892" type="main" key="met"><orth extent="full" lang="la">met</orth>, <itype>a pronominal suffix attached to substantive and</itype> (less freq.) adjective personal pronouns; Engl. <sense id="n28892.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">self</hi>: egomet, mihimet, memet, nosmet, nobismet, tutemet, tibimet, vosmet, meamet; v. ego, tu, and meus.</sense></entryFree>
meta: <entryFree id="n28893" type="main" key="me_ta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mēta</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>root ma-, measure, whence Gr. <foreign lang="greek">me/tron</foreign>; Lat. manus, mane, etc. (q. v.), properly, that which marks a measured space, hence</etym>, <sense id="n28893.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">any mark at a boundary</hi> or <hi rend="ital">limit</hi>, esp., </sense><sense id="n28893.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The conical columns set in the ground at each end of the Roman Circus, the goal, turning-post</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">metaque fervidis Evitata rotis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 1, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aut prius infecto deposcit praemia cursu Septima quam metam triverit ante rota,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:20:25" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 20, 25</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">et modo lora dabo, modo verbere terga notabo, Nunc stringam metas interiore rotā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:3:2:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 3, 2, 11</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:39" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 39</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">petra in metae maxime modum erecta est, cujus ima spatiosiora sunt, altiora in artius coëunt, summa in acutum cacumen exsurgunt,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>in the shape of a cone</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:8:39:6" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 8, 39, 6</bibl></cit>; cf. III. 3. infra).—</sense><sense id="n28893.2" n="II" level="1"> Any <hi rend="ital">goal</hi> or <hi rend="ital">winning-post, the mark, goal</hi>, in any contest of speed: <cit><quote lang="la">optatam cursu contingere metam, of a footrace,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:412" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 412</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">metam tenere, in a boatrace,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:159" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 159</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28893.3" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> (because of the danger to drivers of striking the goal, and breaking their oars), <hi rend="ital">a critical point, place of danger</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fama adulescentis paulum haesit ad metas, notitiā novā mulieris,</quote> <trans><tr>broke down, failed, at the critical point</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:chapter=31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cael. 31</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28893.4" n="III" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">an end, period, extremity, boundary, limit</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">longarum haec meta viarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:714" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 714</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad metas aevi pervenire,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10, 472</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">metam tangere vitae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:1:9:1" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 1, 9, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad metam properare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:2:727" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. A. 2, 727</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ultima,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:3:15:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 3, 15, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hic tibi mortis erant metae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:546" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 546</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad quas metas naturae sit perveniendum usu,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>extremes</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 8:16:31" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 8, 16, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quando illa (luna) incurrat in umbram terrae, quae est meta noctis, eam obscurari necesse est,</quote> <trans><tr>the limit, measure of night</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:6:17" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 6, 17</bibl></cit> (but v. 3. below, <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi> and the passage there cited from Pliny): sol ex aequo metā distabat utrāque, <hi rend="ital">equally far from both ends of his course</hi>, i. e. at noon, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:145" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 145</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">intercalariis mensibus interponendis ita dispensavit (Numa), ut vices uno anno ad metam eandem solis unde orsi essent ... dies congruerent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:19:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 19, 6</bibl></cit> Weissenb. ad loc.: <cit><quote lang="la">metae Marsicae, = fines Marsorum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 4, § 331</bibl></cit> Kapp: <cit><quote lang="la">pares horarum metas, tam antemeridialium quam postremarum, manifestant,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 6, § 600</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28893.5" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A turning-point</hi> in one's course: <cit><quote lang="la">praestat Trinacrii metas lustrare Pachyni,</quote> <trans><tr>to sail around the promontory of Pachynus</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:429" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 429</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28893.6" n="3" level="3"> Of any thing resembling in shape the meta of the Circus; <hi rend="ital">any thing of a conical or pyramidal form, a cone, pyramid</hi> (class.); <cit><quote lang="la">of a conical hill: ipse collis est in modum metae, in acutum cacumen a fundo satis lato fastigatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 37, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">buxus in metas emittitur,</quote> <trans><tr>into cones</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 16, 28, § 70</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in metas foenum exstruere,</quote> <trans><tr>in ricks, haycocks</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:2:18:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 2, 18, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lactantes,</quote> <trans><tr>conical cheeses</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:1:44:7" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 1, 44, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lactis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:3:58:35" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 3, 58, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">meta sudans,</quote> <trans><tr>a conical stone on a fountain, dripping with water</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 56:4" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 56, 4</bibl></cit>: meta molendaria, or molendinaria, <hi rend="ital">that part of the upper millstone which projects downward</hi> and grinds the corn (the upper part is the catillus, q. v.); = Gr. <foreign lang="greek">o)/nos a)le/ths</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:33:7:18:section=5" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 33, 7, 18, § 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">metas molendinarias rotare,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 17, 4, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si minor materia quam lux, metae existere effigiem,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>if the solid body be smaller than the light, its shadow will be conical</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 11, 8, § 51</bibl></cit> (cf. the context).</sense></entryFree>
metabole: <entryFree id="n28894" type="greek" key="me^ta^bo^le_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtăbŏlē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">metabolh/</foreign>, <sense id="n28894.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the transition to another key</hi> or <hi rend="ital">set of tones</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Fulg.</author> Myth. 3, 9, p. 128</bibl> Muncker: cf. <cit><quote lang="la">written as Greek,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:4:50" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 4, 50</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
metabus: <entryFree id="n28895" type="main" key="Me^ta^bus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĕtăbus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <sense id="n28895.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A king of the Volsci, father of Camilla</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:540" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 540</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 252" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 252</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n28895.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A son of Sisyphus, the founder of Metapontum</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 11, 540</bibl>. <cb n="META" /></sense></entryFree>
metacismus: <entryFree id="n28896" type="greek" key="me^ta^cismus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtăcismus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>for mytacismus, = <foreign lang="greek">mutakismo/s</foreign>, from <foreign lang="greek">mu=</foreign></etym>, <sense id="n28896.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a frequent repetition of the letter</hi> M, <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 5, § 514</bibl>; also <hi rend="ital">the pronunciation of</hi> M <hi rend="ital">at the close of a word before a word beginning with a vowel, metacism</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 448</bibl> P.</sense></entryFree>
metagogeus: <entryFree id="n28897" type="greek" key="Me^ta^go_geu^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĕtăgōge[dibreve]ŭs</orth> <itype>ĕi</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">metagwgeu/s</foreign>, <sense id="n28897.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">he who leads around;</hi> Lat. circumductor, one of the aeons of Valentinian, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Valent. 10</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metagon: <entryFree id="n28898" type="main" key="Me^ta^gon"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĕtăgon</orth>, <itype>ontis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*meta/gwn</foreign>, <sense id="n28898.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of a dog</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Grat.</author> Cyn. 209</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metalces: <entryFree id="n28899" type="main" key="Metalces"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Metalces</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*metalkh/s</foreign>, <sense id="n28899.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one of the fifty sons of Ægyptus, slain by his wife Cleopatra</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 170" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 170</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metalepsis: <entryFree id="n28900" type="greek" key="meta^lepsis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">metălepsis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">meta/lhyis</foreign>, <sense id="n28900.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">in rhetoric, the use of one word for another which it suggests by association</hi>, as, the cause for the effect, or the reverse; <cit><quote lang="la">especially when a second substitution is made, as when aristae is said for messis, and then for aestas or annus: est haec in metalepsi natura, ut inter id, quod transfertur, sit medius quidam gradus, nihil ipse significans, sed praebens transitum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:6:38" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 6, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in metalepsin cadit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:3:52" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 6, 3, 52</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
metalis: <entryFree id="n28901" type="main" key="me_ta_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mētālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>meta, III. 3</etym>, <sense id="n28901.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">conical</hi> (post-class.): forma, Paul. ex Fest. s. v. tutulum, p. 335 Müll.—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">mētālĭ-ter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">conically</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">majus corpus ejus quo umbra metaliter jacitur, quam umbra ipsa,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 8, § 859</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 8, § 870</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metallarius: <entryFree id="n28902" type="main" key="me^talla_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtallārĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtallā-rĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>metallum</etym>, <sense id="n28902.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a man</hi> or <hi rend="ital">a woman that works in a mine, a miner</hi> (post-class.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Cod. Just.</author> 11, 6, 7</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metallicus: <entryFree id="n28903" type="main" key="me^talli^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtallĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n28903.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to metal, metallic</hi> (post-Aug.). </sense><sense id="n28903.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Adj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">molybdaena metallica,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:173" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 18, 53, § 173</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">natura,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 27, 4, 5, § 15</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28903.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtallĭcus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> </sense><sense id="n28903.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A digger of metals, a mine-digger, miner</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">lavant eas arenas metallici,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:157" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 16, 47, § 157</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Cod. Just.</author> 11, 6, 7</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n28903.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A person condemned to the mines</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:48:19:10" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 48, 19, 10</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n28903.5" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A worker in stone</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cassiod.</author> Var. 7, 15</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metallifer: <entryFree id="n28904" type="main" key="me^talli^fer"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtallĭfer</orth>, <itype>fĕra, fĕrum</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>metallum-fero</etym>, <sense id="n28904.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">yielding</hi> or <hi rend="ital">abounding in metal, metalliferous</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">terra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:15:500" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 15, 500</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Luna,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:4:4:23" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 4, 4, 23</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
metallinensis: <entryFree id="n28905" type="main" key="Metallinensis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Metallinensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Metellinen-sis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Metallinum</etym>, <sense id="n28905.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to the town of Metallinum</hi> (in Lusitania), <hi rend="ital">Metallinian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">colonia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:117" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 21, 35, § 117</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
metallum: <entryFree id="n28906" type="greek" key="me^tallum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtallum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">me/tallon</foreign>, <sense id="n28906.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a mine</hi> or <hi rend="ital">quarry</hi>, of gold, silver, iron, or stone; <case>voc.</case> metalle, as if from metallus, <bibl default="NO"><author>Spart.</author> Pesc. Nig. 126</bibl>. </sense><sense id="n28906.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">the place where metals are dug, a mine</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">metalla vetera intermissa recoluit, et nova multis locis instituit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sandaracae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:7:7:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 7, 7, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aurifera,</quote> <trans><tr>gold-mines</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:3:209" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 3, 209</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">silicum,</quote> <trans><tr>stone-quarry</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:4:304" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 304</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">miniarium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:118" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 7, 40, § 118</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praeter annuum, quod ex metallis regiis capia, vectigal,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 12</bibl></cit>: herba tantae suavitatis, ut metallum esse coeperit, <hi rend="ital">a mine</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">that a tax was raised from it as from a mine</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 7, 20, § 44</bibl>: damnare in metallum, <hi rend="ital">to condemn to labor in the mines</hi> or <hi rend="ital">quarries</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">damnatus in metallum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:2:11:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 2, 11, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">condemnare aliquem ad metalla,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:27" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mediocrium delictorum poenae sunt metallum, ludus, deportatio,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul.</author> Sent. 5, 17, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">5, 3, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">dare aliquem in metallum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:48:19:8" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 48, 19, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">metallo plecti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:47:11:7" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 47, 11, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">puniri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:48:13:6" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 48, 13, 6</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28906.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">the product of a mine</hi> or <hi rend="ital">quarry</hi>. </sense><sense id="n28906.3" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A metal</hi>, as gold, silver, or iron: <cit><quote lang="la">ubicumque una inventa vena argenti est, non procul invenitur alia. Hoc quidem et in omni fere materia: unde metalla Graeci videntur dixisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33</bibl></cit>. 6, 31, § <cit><quote lang="la">96: auri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:445" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 445</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">potior metallis libertas,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>gold and silver</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 10, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aeris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:165" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 165</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pejoraque saecula ferri temporibus, quorum ... nomen a nullo posuit natura metallo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:13:30" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 13, 30</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28906.4" n="2" level="3"> Other things dug from the earth. </sense><sense id="n28906.5" n="(a)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">Marble</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:4:3:98" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 4, 3, 98</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n28906.6" n="(b)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">Precious stone</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">radiantium metalla gemmarum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Pacat.</author> Pan. 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28906.7" n="(g)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">Chalk</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">admiscetur creta ... Campani negant alicam confici sine eo metallo posse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:114" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 11, 29, § 114</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28906.8" n="(d)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">Sulphur</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">utque est ingenium vivacis metalli (sulphuris),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 9</bibl></cit>. p. 228, 23.—（<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) <hi rend="ital">Salt</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">metallum fragile,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Hamart. 744</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28906.9" n="III" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">metal</hi>, <cb n="META" /> <hi rend="ital">stuff, material</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">saecula meliore metallo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> III. Cons. Hon. 184</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mores meliore metallo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Cons. Mall. Theod. 137</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
metamelos: <entryFree id="n28907" type="greek" key="me^ta^me^los"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtămĕlos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">meta/melos</foreign>, <sense id="n28907.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">repentance</hi> (ante-class.): metamelos, filius inconstantiae, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 79, 23</bibl> (Büch. § 239).</sense></entryFree>
metamorphosis: <entryFree id="n28908" type="greek" key="me^ta^morpho_sis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtămorphōsis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">metamo/rfwsis</foreign>, <sense id="n28908.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a transformation, metamorphosis;</hi> in <number>plur.</number>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĕtămorphōses</orth>, -ĕōn, <hi rend="ital">the Metamorphoses, a well-known poem of Ovid;</hi> in Gr. <hi rend="ital">acc. plur.</hi> Metamorphoseis, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Val. 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">censeo eam rem ad metamorphosis Ovidi adiciendam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Apocol. 9:5" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Apocol. 9, 5</bibl></cit>; in Gr. <hi rend="ital">dat. plur.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut Ovidius lascivire in Metamorphosesi solet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:4:1:77" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 4, 1, 77</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
metanoea: <entryFree id="n28909" type="greek" key="me^ta^noea"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtănoea</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">quadrisyl.</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">meta/noia</foreign>, <sense id="n28909.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">repentance</hi> (post-class.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Epigr. 12, 12</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metaphora: <entryFree id="n28910" type="greek" key="me^tapho^ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtaphŏra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">metafora/</foreign>, <sense id="n28910.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a rhetorical figure, metaphor, a transferring of a word from its proper signification to another</hi> (called by <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:38:155" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 38, 155</bibl>, verbi translatio; <cit><quote lang="la">post-Aug.),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:6:18" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 6, 18</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">(as Greek),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:6:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 8, 6, 4</bibl></cit> sqq.; Schol. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:1:169" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 1, 169</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metaphorice: <entryFree id="n28911" type="main" key="me^tapho^ri^ce_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtaphŏrĭcē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>metaphora</etym>, <sense id="n28911.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">metaphorically, figuratively</hi> (post-class.), Acron. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 20, 1</bibl>.—Also <orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtaphŏrĭ-cōs</orth>, <foreign lang="greek">metaforikw=s</foreign>, Acron. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 3, 29 sq.</bibl>; Schol. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:7:103" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 7, 103</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metaphrenum: <entryFree id="n28912" type="greek" key="me^ta^phre^num"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtăphrĕnum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">meta/frenon</foreign>, <sense id="n28912.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the upper part of the spine</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Acut. 3:16:129" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Acut. 3, 16, 129</bibl> (as Greek, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:ib. 2:29:151" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 29, 151</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Tard. 3:2:31" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tard. 3, 2, 31</bibl>).</sense></entryFree>
metapinus: <entryFree id="n28913" type="main" key="Me^ta^pi_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĕtăpīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype> <etym>etym. dub.</etym>, <sense id="n28913.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Metapinic</hi>, an epithet of the second or middle of the three principal mouths of the Rhone: <cit><quote lang="la">cujus ora appellata ... alterum Metapinum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 6, § 635</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 4, 5, § 32</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metaplasmus: <entryFree id="n28914" type="greek" key="me^taplasmus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtaplasmus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">metaplasmo/s</foreign>, <sense id="n28914.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a grammatical change, irregularity, metaplasm</hi>, e. g. in declension (post-Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">metaplasmus enim, et schematismos et schemata vocamus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:8:14" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 8, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 3, § 326</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metaplasticos: <entryFree id="n28915" type="greek" key="me^taplasti^co_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtaplastĭcōs</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">metaplastikw=s</foreign>, <sense id="n28915.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">metaplastically, by the use of metaplasm</hi>: metaplasticos dicitur apud poëtas usurpari id quod propter necessitatem metri mutare consueverunt, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=153" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 153</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
metapontinus: <entryFree id="n28916" type="main" key="Me^ta^ponti_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĕtăpontīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. Metapontum.</entryFree>
metapontum: <entryFree id="n28917" type="main" key="Me^ta^pontum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĕtăpontum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n28917.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town of Lucania, where Pythagoras lived and died</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Torre a Mare</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:2:4" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 5, 2, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:18:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 18, 8</bibl>; Mela, 2, 4, 3; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:97" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 11, 15, § 97</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĕtăpontīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., Metapontine</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ager,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 20</bibl></cit>.—In <number>plur.</number>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĕtă-pontīni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the Metapontines</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 61</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metarius: <entryFree id="n28918" type="main" key="me_ta_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mētārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>meta</etym>, <sense id="n28918.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to limits</hi> or <hi rend="ital">boundaries</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">metaria circumscriptio,</quote> <trans><tr>a limiting by boundaries</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 2, 70</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
metastasis: <entryFree id="n28919" type="greek" key="me^tasta^sis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtastăsis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">meta/stasis</foreign>, a rhet. figure. <sense id="n28919.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A refusing</hi>, Agn. Roman. de Fig. 16, p. 155.—</sense><sense id="n28919.1" n="II" level="1"> = metabasis, <hi rend="ital">a passing over, transition</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Julian.</author> Rufin. de Schem. 23, p. 243</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metasyncriticus: <entryFree id="n28920" type="greek" key="me^ta^syncri^ti^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtăsyncrĭtĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">metasugkritiko/s</foreign>, <sense id="n28920.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">belonging to the discharge of peccant humors</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adjutoria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Acut. 3:16:134" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Acut. 3, 16, 134</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cyclus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Tard. 1:1:24" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tard. 1, 1, 24</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:2:1:49" default="NO">2, 1, 49</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metathesis: <entryFree id="n28921" type="main" key="me^ta^the^sis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtăthĕsis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">meta/qesis</foreign>, <sense id="n28921.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a transposition of the letters of a word</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> 2, p. 437</bibl> P.</sense></entryFree>
metatio: <entryFree id="n28922" type="main" key="me_ta_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mētātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>metor</etym>, <sense id="n28922.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a measuring</hi> or <hi rend="ital">meting out, a marking off</hi> a place (postAug.): <cit><quote lang="la">vinearum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:7:15:1" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 7, 15, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
metator: <entryFree id="n28923" type="main" key="me_ta_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mētātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n28923.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who metes out</hi> or <hi rend="ital">marks off</hi> a place, <hi rend="ital">a divider and fixer of boundaries</hi> (class.). </sense><sense id="n28923.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">castrorum antea metator, nunc, ut sperat, urbis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:11:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 11, 5, 12</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 14, 4, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">templi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 4, 11</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28923.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a measurer</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tempus arbiter et metator initii et finis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Marc. 1, 8</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
metatorius: <entryFree id="n28924" type="main" key="me_ta_to_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mētātōrĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>metator</etym>, <sense id="n28924.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to measuring out</hi>, transf. (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">pagina,</quote> <trans><tr>a letter relative to the providing of quarters</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 8, 11</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
metatura: <entryFree id="n28925" type="main" key="me_ta_tu_ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mētātūra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>metor</etym>, <sense id="n28925.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a measuring out, marking off</hi> a place (eccl. Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 4, 11, 13</bibl>. <pb n="1140" /> <cb n="METH" /></sense></entryFree>
metaurensis: <entryFree id="n28926" type="main" key="Me^taurensis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĕtaurensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Metaurus</etym>, <sense id="n28926.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to the river Metaurus, in Umbria</hi>: AGER, Inscr. Oliv. Marm. Pisaur. n. 30.—<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĕtaurenses</orth>, <itype>ĭum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of that region, Metaurians</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:114" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 14, 19, § 114</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metaurus: <entryFree id="n28927" type="main" key="Me^taurus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĕtaurus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*me/tauros</foreign>, <sense id="n28927.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of several rivers</hi>. </sense><sense id="n28927.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A river in Umbria, celebrated for the defeat of Hasdrubal, the brother of Hannibal</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Meturo</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:43 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 27, 43 sq.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:8:486" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 8, 486</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĕtau-rus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., of Metaurus</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Metaurum flumen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:4:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 4, 38</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28927.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A river in the Bruttian territory</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Marro</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 10, § 73</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metaxa: <entryFree id="n28928" type="greek" key="me^taxa"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtaxa</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">mătaxa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">me/taca</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">ma/taca</foreign>, <sense id="n28928.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">raw silk</hi>, the web of silkworms. </sense><sense id="n28928.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:39:4:16" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 39, 4, 16</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Cod. Just.</author> 11, 7, 10</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n28928.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a rope</hi>: lini metaxa, Lucil. ap. Fest. s. v. rodus, p. 265 Müll.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:7:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 7, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metaxarii: <entryFree id="n28929" type="main" key="me^taxa_ri^i"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtaxārĭi</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>metaxa</etym>, <sense id="n28929.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">silkdealers</hi> (post-class.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Cod. Just.</author> 8, 14, 27</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metella: <entryFree id="n28930" type="main" key="me^tella"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtella</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (prob. <pos>adj.</pos>, sc. machina), <sense id="n28930.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a basket filled with stones, which the besieged threw down on the heads of the besiegers</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">ut de ligno crates facerent, quas metellas vocaverunt, lapidibusque complerent, etc. (al. metilas, medullas, metulas),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> Mil. 4, 6</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
metellinus: <entryFree id="n28931" type="main" key="Me^telli_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĕtellīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Metellus</etym>, <sense id="n28931.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to a Metellus, Metelline</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">oratlo Metellina,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>against Metellus</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 13 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
metellus: <entryFree id="n28932" type="main" key="Me^tellus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĕtellus</orth>, <itype>a</itype> <etym>etym. dub.; metellus = <foreign lang="greek">misqios</foreign>, hired, i. e. a hired servant, Gloss. Philox.: metelli dicuntur in re militari quasi mercenarii, Attius in Annalibus: calones famulique metellique caculaeque; a quo genere hominum Caeciliae familiae cognomen putatur ductum, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=146" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 146</bibl> and 147 Müll.</etym>, <sense id="n28932.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of a Roman family in the</hi> gens Caecilia; its most famous members were: </sense><sense id="n28932.1" n="1" level="3"> Q. Metellus Macedonicus, who made Macedonia a Roman province, and was renowned for his good-fortune, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:1:11:1" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 1, 11, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:35:85" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 35, 85</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 36, 86</bibl>, etc.—</sense><sense id="n28932.2" n="2" level="3"> Quintus Caecilius Metellus Numidicus, who defeated Jugurtha in Numidia, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 43</bibl> sqq.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:35:135" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 35, 135</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n28932.3" n="3" level="3"> L. Caecilius Metellus, who saved the palladium from the burning temple of Vesta, B. C. 241, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:Epit. 19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> Epit. 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:2:2:27" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 2, 2, 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:1:1" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 1, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:6:265" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 6, 265</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:3:137 sq" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 3, 137 sq.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n28932.4" n="4" level="3"> C. Caecilius Metellus Celer, Cicero's contemporary, and husband of Coelia, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 2, 1, 5</bibl>, etc. —</sense><sense id="n28932.5" n="5" level="3"> Qu. Caecilius Metellus Pius (Scipio), son of Scipio Nasica, and Pompey's fatherin-law, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:15:5" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 15, 5</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n28932.6" n="6" level="3"> Caecilia Metella, wife of P. Cornelius Lentulus Spinther, divorced A. U. C. 709, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:239" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 3, 239</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:11:23:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 11, 23, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">13, 7, 1</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n28932.7" n="7" level="3"> Caecilia Metella, wife of M. Aemilius Scaurus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:47:101" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 47, 101</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metempsychosis: <entryFree id="n28933" type="greek" key="me^tempsy_cho_sis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtempsȳchōsis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">metemyu/xwsis</foreign>, <sense id="n28933.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the transit of the soul, its transmigration from one body to another</hi>, a doctrine of the Pythagoreans, Porphyr. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 52</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metensomatosis: <entryFree id="n28934" type="greek" key="me^tenso_ma^to_sis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtensōmătōsis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">metenswma/twsis</foreign>, <sense id="n28934.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a removing from one body into another, a change of body</hi> (eccl. Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Anim. 31</bibl> and 32.</sense></entryFree>
meteoria: <entryFree id="n28935" type="greek" key="me^te^o_ri^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtĕōrĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">metewri/a</foreign>, <sense id="n28935.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">forgetfulness</hi>, M. Aurel. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:ad M. Caes. 4:7" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> ad M. Caes. 4, 7</bibl> (as Greek, Suet. Vit. Claud.).</sense></entryFree>
meterea: <entryFree id="n28936" type="hapax" key="Me^te^re_a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĕtĕrēa turba</orth>, <sense id="n28936.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a people dwelling about the Danube and the Black Sea</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:2:191" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 2, 191</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
methion: <entryFree id="n28937" type="main" key="Me_thi_on"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mēthīon</orth>, <itype>ŏnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n28937.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the father of Phorbas</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 74</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
methodice: <entryFree id="n28938" type="greek" key="me^tho^di^ce_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕthŏdĭcē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">meqodikh/</foreign>, <sense id="n28938.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the methodical part of grammar</hi> (post-Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">grammaticae partes duae, id est ratio loquendi, et enarratio auctorum: quarum illam methodicen, hanc historicen vocant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:9:1" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 9, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
methodicus: <entryFree id="n28939" type="greek" key="me^tho^di^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕthŏdĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">meqodiko/s</foreign>, <sense id="n28939.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">methodical, belonging to a particular school</hi> (post-Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">medicina,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Anim. 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">disciplina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Tard. 4:1:6" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Tard. 4, 1, 6</bibl></cit>: medici, Cels. praef. § 13.</sense></entryFree>
methodium: <entryFree id="n28940" type="greek" key="me^tho^di^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕthŏdĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">meqo/dion</foreign>, <sense id="n28940.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a witty conceit, a jest, joke</hi> (post-Aug.): Trimalchio ejusmodi methodio laetus, Carpe, inquit,<cb n="METI" />  etc. (al. metōdīum, i. e. <foreign lang="greek">metwdei=on</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">an inserted song</hi>), <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 36, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
methodus: <entryFree id="n28941" type="greek" key="me^tho^dus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕthŏdus</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕthŏdos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">me/qodos</foreign>, <sense id="n28941.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a way of teaching, mode of proceeding, method</hi> (post-class.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:1:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 1, 1, 4</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Idyll. 11, 67</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Tard. 2:1:49" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Tard. 2, 1, 49</bibl> (as Greek, Cels. praef. § 91); cf. methodicus.</sense></entryFree>
methymna: <entryFree id="n28942" type="main" key="Me_thymna"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mēthymna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*mh/qumna</foreign>, <sense id="n28942.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city in the island of Lesbos, famous as the birthplace of the poet Arion, and for its excellent wine</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Molivo</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:7:4" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 7, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:31:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 31, 14</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quot habet Methymna racemos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:1:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 1, 57</bibl></cit>.—Hence. </sense><sense id="n28942.1" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Mēthymnaeus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">*mhqumnai=os</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Methymna, Methymnean</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Lesbos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:11:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 11, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Arion,</quote> <trans><tr>of Methymna</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:27:67" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 27, 67</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">merum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4</bibl></cit> (5), 8, 38: <cit><quote lang="la">palmes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 90</bibl></cit>.—In <hi rend="ital">plur. subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Mēthymnaei</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the Methymneans</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:5:19" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 5, 19</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n28942.2" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Mēthymnĭas</orth>, <itype>ădis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <hi rend="ital">adj., Methymnian</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">Methymniades puellae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:15:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 15, 15</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
metia: <entryFree id="n28943" type="spur" key="Meti^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Metĭa Porta</orth>, a false read. in Plaut.; cf. Ritschl ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:3:97" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 3, 97</bibl>.</entryFree>
meticulosus: <entryFree id="n28944" type="main" key="me^ti^cu^lo_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtĭcŭlōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>metus</etym>, <sense id="n28944.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">full of fear</hi>. </sense><sense id="n28944.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Fearful, timid</hi> (ante- and postclass.): <cit><quote lang="la">nullus est hoc meticulosus aeque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:137" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 137</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:4:2:7" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 4, 2, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">lepus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Flor. p. 341, 9</bibl></cit>.—* </sense><sense id="n28944.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Frightful, terrible</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">res,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:5:1:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 5, 1, 52</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
metilius: <entryFree id="n28945" type="main" key="Metilius"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Metilius</orth>, <itype>a</itype>, <sense id="n28945.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Roman family name</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">M. Metilius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 11</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Meti-lius</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to a Metilius</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Metilia lex,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:197" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 17, 57, § 197</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
metina: <entryFree id="n28946" type="main" key="Metina"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Metina</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n28946.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an island near the coast of Gaul, opposite the mouth of the Rhone</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 6, § 643</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metior: <entryFree id="n28947" type="main" key="me_ti^or"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mētĭor</orth>, <itype>mensus</itype> (post-class. metītus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:32:1:52" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 32, 1, 52</bibl>), <itype>4</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> <etym>Sanscr. ma, to measure; cf. Gr. <foreign lang="greek">me/-tron</foreign>, Lat. modus</etym>, <sense id="n28947.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to measure, mete</hi> (lands, corn); also, <hi rend="ital">to measure</hi> or <hi rend="ital">mete out, to deal out, distribute by measure</hi> (class.). </sense><sense id="n28947.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">metiri agrum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:17:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 17, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">frumentum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:83:section=192" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 83, § 192</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sol, quem metiri non possunt,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 41, 128</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">magnitudinem mundi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:43:154" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 43, 154</bibl></cit>: nummos, <hi rend="ital">to measure one's money</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to have a great abundance of it</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:1:95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 1, 95</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nummos modio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0972,001:37" default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> S. 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">se ad candelabrum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 75</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedes syllabis,</quote> <trans><tr>to measure by syllables</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:57:194" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 57, 194</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">frumentum militibus metiri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum exercitu frumentum metiri oporteret,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 23</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">7, 71: Caecubum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:9:36" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 9, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quis mensus est pugillo aquas?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,048:40:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Isa. 40, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tantus acervus fuit, ut metientibus dimidium super tres modios explesse, sint quidam auctores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 23, 12</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28947.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg> transf., <hi rend="ital">to measure</hi> a distance, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to pass, walk</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">sail through</hi> or <hi rend="ital">over, to traverse</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Sacram metiente te viam (of the measured pace of a proud person),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:4:7" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 4, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aequor curru,</quote> <trans><tr>to sail through</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:389" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 389</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aquas carinā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:446" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 446</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tu, cursu, dea menstruo metiens iter annuom,</quote> <trans><tr>to go through complete</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:34:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 34, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">instabili gressu metitur litora cornix,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:5:556" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 5, 556</bibl></cit>.—Also <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quin hic metimur gradibus militariis,</quote> <trans><tr>to walk</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:4:4:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 4, 4, 11</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28947.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to measure, estimate, judge</hi> one thing by another; also simply <hi rend="ital">to measure, estimate, judge of, set a value on</hi> a thing. </sense><sense id="n28947.4" n="(a)" level="5"> With <case>abl.</case> of the standard of comparison, or the means of judgment: <cit><quote lang="la">sonantia metiri auribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:68:227" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 68, 227</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oculo latus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:2:103" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 2, 103</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia quaestu,</quote> <trans><tr>by profit</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:43:111" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 43, 111</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui nihil alterius causa faciet et metietur suis commodis omnia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:14:41" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 1, 14, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vides igitur, si amicitiam sua caritate metiare, nihil esse praestantius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:26:85" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 26, 85</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vim eloquentiae sua facultate non rei natura,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,041:Or. 4:10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Opt. Gen. Or. 4, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia voluptate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:12:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 7, 12, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">studia utilitate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:11:29" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 11, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">magnos homines virtute, non fortuna,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,018:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Eum. 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">usum pecuniae non magnitudine, sed ratione,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:chapter=14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">officia utilitate,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 6, 11, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">odium in se aliorum suo in eos metiens odio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pericula suo metu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 31:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 31, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">peccata vitiis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,047:3:1:20" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Par. 3, 1, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aetatem nostram non spatio senectutis, sed tempore adulescentiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:11:13" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 11, 13</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28947.5" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">ex</hi> (very rare): <cit><quote lang="la">fidelitas, quam ego ex mea conscientiā metior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 4, 2</bibl></cit>: ex eo, quantum cuique satis est, metiuntur homines <cb n="METO" /> divitiarum modum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,047:6:1:14" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Par. 6, 1, 14</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n28947.6" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec se metitur ad illum quem dedit haec (paupertas) posuitque modum,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>accommodates herself</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:6:358" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 6, 358</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28947.7" n="(d)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg> (post-Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">metiri ac diligenter aestimare vires suas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:1:45" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 1, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pondera sua,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:12:100:8" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 12, 100, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sua regna,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:8:527" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 8, 527</bibl></cit>. —（<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">quod</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quanto metiris pretio, quod, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:9:72" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 9, 72</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28947.8" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To traverse. go over, pass through</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">late Aequora prospectu metior alta meo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:10:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 10, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tot casus, tot avia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:5:476" default="NO"><author>Val.
