Fl.</author> 5, 476</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jamque duas lucis partes Hyperione menso,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:564" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 564</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28947.9" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To measure out, deal to</hi> any one, <hi rend="ital">treat</hi> one <hi rend="ital">well</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ill</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mensurā quā mensi fueritis, remetietur vobis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:6:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Luc. 6, 38</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:7:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Matt. 7, 2</bibl>.!*? In <hi rend="ital">pass. signif., to be measured</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">agri glebatim metiebantur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> Mort. Persec. 23, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">an sol pedis unius latitudine metiatur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 2, 86</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Part. perf.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">mensus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">measured off</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mensa spatia conficere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:27:69" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 27, 69</bibl></cit>.—As <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">bene mensum dabo,</quote> <trans><tr>good measure</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 4:4:1" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Q. N. 4, 4, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
metiosedum: <entryFree id="n28948" type="main" key="Me^ti^o_se_dum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĕtĭōsēdum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n28948.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city in Gaul</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Meudon</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 61</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metiscus: <entryFree id="n28949" type="main" key="Metiscus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Metiscus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n28949.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a charioteer of Turnus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:469" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 469</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metitio: <entryFree id="n28950" type="gloss" key="me_ti_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mētītĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>metior</etym>, = mensura, but not in use; v. <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> 374</bibl> P.</entryFree>
metitor: <entryFree id="n28951" type="main" key="me_ti_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mētītor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>metior</etym>, <sense id="n28951.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a measurer</hi> (post-Aug.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:Aquaed. 79" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> Aquaed. 79</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metitus: <entryFree id="n28952" type="main" key="me_ti_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mētītus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. metior <sense id="n28952.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">init.</hi></sense></entryFree>
metius: <entryFree id="n28953" type="main" key="Meti^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Metĭus</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Mettĭus</orth> (also <orth extent="full" lang="la">Mettus</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n28953.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an Italian proper name</hi>. </sense><sense id="n28953.1" n="I" level="1"> Metius (Mettius) Curtius, <hi rend="ital">a Sabine chief</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 12 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=149" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 149</bibl> Müll.—</sense><sense id="n28953.2" n="II" level="1"> Metius Fufetius (acc. to others, Mettus Fufetius), <hi rend="ital">an Alban general, who was put to death by the command of</hi> Tullus Hostilius, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:23 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 23 sq.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:642" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 642</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:1:3:8" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 1, 3, 8</bibl>.—In <hi rend="ital">gen. sing.</hi>: Mettoi Fubettoi, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:5:12" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 5, 12</bibl> (Ann. v. 129 Vahl.; Halm, Mettoeo Fufettioeo).—</sense><sense id="n28953.3" n="III" level="1"> M. Metius, <hi rend="ital">a friend of Ariovistus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 47</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 53</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
meto: <entryFree id="n28954" type="main" key="me_to1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mēto</orth> (no <sense id="n28954.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">perf.</hi>), ātum, 1, <hi rend="ital">v. a., to measure;</hi> v. metor <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n28955" type="main" key="me^to2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕto</orth>, <itype>messŭi</itype> (Cato ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 903</bibl> P.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 3, § 319</bibl>), <itype>messum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> and <gen>n.</gen> <etym>root ma-; Gr. <foreign lang="greek">a)ma/w</foreign>, mow, reap; <foreign lang="greek">a)/mh</foreign>, sickle; cf. messis, messor</etym>, <sense id="n28955.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to reap, mow, crop;</hi> of the vintage, <hi rend="ital">to gather, gather in, collect;</hi> and <usg type="style">poet.</usg> of the <hi rend="ital">sucking</hi> of honey from flowers (class.). </sense><sense id="n28955.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum est matura seges, metendum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:50:3" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 50, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sunt autem metendi genera complura,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:2:21:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 2, 21, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in metendo occupatos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:4:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 4, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pabula falce,</quote> <trans><tr>to cut, cut down</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:6:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 6, 84</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">farra,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> F 2, 519</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arva,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4</bibl></cit> (5), 10, 30.—Prov.: <cit><quote lang="la">ut sementem feceris, ita et metes,</quote> <trans><tr>as you sow, so shall you reap</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:65:261" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 65, 261</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">ventum seminabunt et turbinem metent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,036:8:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Os. 8, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui seminant iniquitatem metet mala,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,029:22:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Prov. 22, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mihi istic nec seritur, nec metitur,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>I have no share in it, it does not concern me</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:2:2:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 80</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sibi quisque ruri metit,</quote> <trans><tr>every one looks out for himself</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:3:2:112" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 3, 2, 112</bibl></cit>: Tibi aras, tibi occas, tibi seris; <cit><quote lang="la">tibi item metes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:prol. 71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Merc. prol. 71</bibl></cit>.—Of the vintage, <hi rend="ital">to gather</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">postremus metito,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:410" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 410</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">vindemiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:185" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 22, 35, § 185</bibl></cit>.—Of bees: purpureosque metunt flores, <hi rend="ital">reap the flowers</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">gather the pollen</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 54</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n28955.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n28955.3" n="A" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to cut off, pluck off, crop</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">virgā lilia summa metit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:2:706" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 2, 706</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">barbam forfice,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:7:95:12" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 7, 95, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">capillos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:10:83:11" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 10, 83, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">olus,</quote> <trans><tr>to cut, gather</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0830,001:2:74" default="NO"><author>Calp.</author> Ecl. 2, 74</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">et ferus in silvā farra metebat aper,</quote> <trans><tr>laid waste</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:3:10:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 3, 10, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ille metit barbam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:3:186" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 3, 186</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n28955.4" n="2" level="3"> In partic., in battle, <hi rend="ital">to mow down, cut down</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">proxima quaeque metit gladio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:513" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 513</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">primosque et extremos metendo Stravit humum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:14:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 14, 31</bibl></cit> tum Vesulum ense metit rapido, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:10:147" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 10, 147</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">agmina plura metam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:3:670" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 3, 670</bibl></cit>.—So of death: <cit><quote lang="la">metit Orcus Grandia cum parvis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 178</bibl></cit>: vita omnibus metenda, ut fruges (transl. of the Greek of Euripid.: <foreign lang="greek">a)nagkai/ws d) e)/xei bi/on qeri/zein</foreign>), Poët. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:25:59" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 25, 59</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n28955.5" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To inhabit</hi> a region (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">qui Batulum Nucrasque metunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:8:566" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 8, 566</bibl></cit> (cf. a like poetic transfer of the verbs colere, arare, serere, and bibere).</sense></entryFree>
<entryFree id="n28956" type="main" key="Me^to3" n="3"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĕto</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, v <usg type="style">Meton.</usg></entryFree>
metoche: <entryFree id="n28957" type="greek" key="me^to^che_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtŏchē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">metoxh/</foreign>, <sense id="n28957.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a participle</hi> (late Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Epigr. 6, 7</bibl>. <pb n="1141" /> <cb n="METR" /></sense></entryFree>
metodium: <entryFree id="n28958" type="main" key="me^to^di^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtŏdĭum</orth>, v. methodium.</entryFree>
metoecus: <entryFree id="n28959" type="greek" key="me^toecus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtoecus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">me/toikos</foreign>, <sense id="n28959.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a stranger, sojourner, denizen, resident alien</hi> dwelling in a city without the rights of citizenship (post-class.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Eum.</author> Pan. Flavens. Nom. Dict. 4 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ager militi metoeco (al. modico) est assignatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:de Colon. p. 134" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> de Colon. p. 134</bibl></cit> Goes. (written <orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtycus</orth>, Gromat. Vet. 234, 19; 238, 7 Lachm.).</sense></entryFree>
meton: <entryFree id="n28960" type="main" key="Me^ton"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĕton</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĕto</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*me/twn</foreign>, <sense id="n28960.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a celebrated Athenian astronomer, who discovered the cycle of nineteen years, at the end of which the new and full moons again fall on the same days</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Avien.</author> Prognost. 48</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Epis. 2, 12</bibl>.—Hence Cicero says, jestingly, of a debtor named Meton, who promised to pay in a year's time: <cit><quote lang="la">quando iste Metonis annus veniet?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 12, 3, 2</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 12, 51, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metonymia: <entryFree id="n28961" type="greek" key="me^to_ny^mi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtōnymĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">metwnumi/a</foreign>, <sense id="n28961.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a figure by which one name is changed for another, a change of names, metonymy</hi> (pure Lat. denominatio), Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=153" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 153</bibl> Müll.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 244</bibl> P. al.</sense></entryFree>
metonymicos: <entryFree id="n28962" type="greek" key="me^to_ny^mi^co_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtōnymĭcōs</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">metwnumikw=s</foreign>, <sense id="n28962.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">metonymically, by metonymy</hi>, Porphyr. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:13:16" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 13, 16</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ad Hor. Ep. 1, 18, 9</bibl> sqq. al.</sense></entryFree>
metopa: <entryFree id="n28963" type="greek" key="me^to^pa"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtŏpa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">meto/ph</foreign>, <sense id="n28963.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the space between two hollows;</hi> in architecture, <hi rend="ital">the space between two dentils</hi> or <hi rend="ital">two triglyphs, a metope</hi> (only in Vitr.): <cit><quote lang="la">inter denticulos et inter triglyphos quae sunt intervalla, metopae nominantur, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:4:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 4, 2, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
metopion: <entryFree id="n28964" type="greek" key="me^to_pi^on"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtōpĭon</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">-um</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (also <orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕ-tops</orth>, <itype>ōpis</itype>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 40</bibl>), = <foreign lang="greek">metw/pion</foreign>. <sense id="n28964.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The gum of an African tree, also called</hi> ammoniacum, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 12, 23, 49, § 107</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 27, 47</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n28964.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Oil of bitter almonds, almond-oil</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 7, 7, § 26</bibl> (Jahn, neopum).—</sense><sense id="n28964.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An ointment made with galbanum</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:13:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 13, 1, 2, § 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metoposcopus: <entryFree id="n28965" type="greek" key="me^to_posco^pus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtōposcŏpus</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">-os</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">metwposko/pos</foreign>, <sense id="n28965.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a forehead inspector, one who tells fortunes by examining the forehead, a metoposcopist</hi> (post-Aug.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tit.:2" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tit. 2</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:88" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 10, 36, § 88</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metops: <entryFree id="n28966" type="main" key="me^tops"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtops</orth>, <itype>ŏpis, for metopion</itype>, v. h. v.</entryFree>
metor: <entryFree id="n28967" type="main" key="me_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mētor</orth>, <itype>ātus, 1</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> <etym>meta</etym>, <sense id="n28967.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to measure, mete; to measure off, mark out</hi> (not in Cic.). </sense><sense id="n28967.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">stadium Hercules pedibus suis metatus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1:1:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 1, 1, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">caelum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:309" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 1, 309</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Indiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 17, 21, § 57</bibl></cit>. —<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to traverse, pass through</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc nemoris alti densa metatur loca,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Hippol. 505" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Hippol. 505</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agros,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:6:58" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 6, 58</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28967.2" n="II" level="1"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n28967.3" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Act., to measure out, mark</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">lay out</hi>: castra metati signa statuunt, Cael. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 137, 18</bibl>: castra, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:13:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 13, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ortu solis castra metabatur,</quote> <trans><tr>measured out the ground for a camp, encamped, pitched his camp</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 106:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 106, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agrum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agros,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:274" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 274</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eam (i. e. Alexandriam),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 10, 11, § 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">regiones (for a temple),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:10:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 10, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">castra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,013:20:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 3 Reg. 20, 27</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28967.4" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Neutr., to encamp, pitch one's tent</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">metarique sub ipso templo ... jussit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:7:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 44, 7, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">post tabernaculum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,004:3:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Num. 3, 23</bibl></cit>.—Hence, transf., <hi rend="ital">to erect, pitch, set up</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tabernacula ciliciis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:143" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 28, 32, § 143</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Act.</hi> collat. form, <orth extent="full" lang="la">mēto</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <hi rend="ital">to measure, measure out</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">loca,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Verg.</author> Cul. 172</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Pass.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">locus metatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Thyest. 462" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Thyest. 462</bibl></cit>.—Often in <hi rend="ital">part. perf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">castris eo loco metatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0530,001:B. G. 8:15" default="NO"><author>Hirt.</author> B. G. 8, 15</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">castra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:37:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 44, 37, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">porticus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:15:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 15, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agellus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:2:114" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 2, 2, 114</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">prope Beroeam vallo metato,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 31, 9, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
metreta: <entryFree id="n28968" type="greek" key="me^tre_ta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtrēta</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">metrhth/s</foreign>, <sense id="n28968.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an Athenian measure for liquids, containing</hi> 12 congii (<foreign lang="greek">xo/es</foreign>) <hi rend="ital">and</hi> 144 <foreign lang="greek">kotu/lai</foreign> (3/4 <hi rend="ital">of the Attic medimnus, about</hi> 9 <hi rend="ital">gallons English</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">picis liquidae metreta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:22:1" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 12, 22, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">se vendidisse navem, metretas quae trecentas tolleret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:prol. 75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. prol. 75</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28968.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a tun, cask, jar</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">oleum si in metretam novam inditurus eris,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 100</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Hispanae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:5:16:7" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 5, 16, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">olivariae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:47" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 12, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hic tignum capiti incutit, ille metretam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:3:246" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 3, 246</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
metricus: <entryFree id="n28969" type="greek" key="me_^tri^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mē^trĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">metriko/s</foreign>, <sense id="n28969.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">relating to measuring</hi> or <hi rend="ital">measure</hi> (postAug.). </sense><sense id="n28969.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">leges metricae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:219" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 37, 88, § 219</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28969.2" n="II" level="1"> In partic., <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">relating to metre, metrical</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">metrici pedes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:4:52" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 4, 52</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:48" default="NO">48</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n28969.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">mē^trĭcus</orth>,<cb n="METU" />  <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a prosodian</hi> (post-class.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:18:15:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 18, 15, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metrocomia: <entryFree id="n28970" type="greek" key="me_tro^co_mi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mētrŏcōmĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">mhtrokwmi/a</foreign>, <sense id="n28970.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a village from which other villages have derived their inhabitants, a mother-village</hi> (post-class.), Cod. Th. 11, 24, 6; <bibl default="NO"><author>Cod. Just.</author> 8, 10, 19</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metrodorus: <entryFree id="n28971" type="main" key="Me_tro^do_rus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mētrŏdōrus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*mhtro/dwros</foreign>. <sense id="n28971.0" n="I" level="1"> Metrodorus Lampsacenus or Atheniensis, <hi rend="ital">an Epicurean</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:3:8" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 3, 8</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 6, 17</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 9, 27</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n28971.1" n="II" level="1"> M. Scepsius (from Scepsis, <hi rend="ital">a city of Mysia</hi>), <hi rend="ital">a rhetorical and Academic philosopher, famous for his memory</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:88:360" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 88, 360</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 20, 75</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 7, 16, § 34</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n28971.2" n="III" level="1"> M. Stratonicēus (from Stratonice, <hi rend="ital">a city of Caria</hi>), <hi rend="ital">a pupil of Carneades, and an excellent orator</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:11:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 11, 45</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 6, 16</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n28971.3" n="IV" level="1"> Metrodorus Chius, <hi rend="ital">a pupil of Democritus and teacher of Anaxarchus and of the fourth Hippocrates</hi> (about B. C. 330), <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 23, 73</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n28971.4" n="V" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A freedman of Cicero</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:15:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 15, 1</bibl>, B, 2; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:16:20:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 16, 20, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metropolis: <entryFree id="n28972" type="greek" key="me_tro^po^lis1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mētrŏpŏlis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">mhtro/polis</foreign>, <sense id="n28972.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city from which other cities have been colonized, a mother-city;</hi> also, the <hi rend="ital">chief city, metropolis</hi> of a province (post-class.). </sense><sense id="n28972.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cod. Just.</author> 11, 21</bibl>; Cod. Th. 13, 3, 11.— </sense><sense id="n28972.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">metropolis et arx mentis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> adv. Jovin. 2, 8</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n28973" type="main" key="Me_tro^po^lis2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mētrŏpŏlis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*mhtro/polis</foreign>, <sense id="n28973.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the proper name of several cities</hi>, e. g. <hi rend="ital">in Thessaly, between Pharsalus and Gomphi</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 80</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:32:13:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 32, 13, 11</bibl>.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">Mētrŏ-pŏlītae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Metropolis</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 81</bibl>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">of others,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:106" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 29, 29, § 106</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:120" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 29, 31, § 120</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metropolita: <entryFree id="n28974" type="greek" key="me_tro^po^li_ta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mētrŏ-pŏlīta</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">mhtropoli/ths</foreign>, <sense id="n28974.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a bishop in a chief city, a metropolitan</hi> (post-class.): metropolita sacer, Ven. Carm. 3, 6, 20.</sense></entryFree>
metropolitae: <entryFree id="n28975" type="main" key="Me_tro^po^li_tae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mētrŏpŏlītae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, v. 2. Metropolis.</entryFree>
metropolitanus: <entryFree id="n28976" type="main" key="me_tro^po^li_ta_nus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mētrŏpŏlītānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>1. metropolis</etym>, <sense id="n28976.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to a metropolis, metropolitan</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">nomen,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cod. Just.</author> 11, 21, 1</bibl></cit>.—Esp. <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Mētrŏ-pŏlītānus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a metropolitan, the bishop of a metropolitan church</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 7, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n28977" type="main" key="Me_tro^po^li_ta_nus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mētrŏpŏlītānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>2. Metropolis</etym>, <sense id="n28977.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to the city of Metropolis</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">campus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 15</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
metrum: <entryFree id="n28978" type="greek" key="me_^trum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mē^trum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">me/tron</foreign>, <sense id="n28978.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a measure;</hi> in partic., <hi rend="ital">a poetical measure, metre; a verse</hi> (post-Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">rhythmi, id est numeri, spatio temporum constant: metra etiam ordine: ideoque alterum esse quantitatis videtur, alterum qualitatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:4:46" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 4, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">metri necessitate cogi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:6:17" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 8, 6, 17</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:6:2" default="NO">1, 6, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">metri causā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:4:17:9" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 4, 17, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Tibulli,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>elegiac metre</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:4:6:4" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 4, 6, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exceptis metris Vergilii,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>verses</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:3:10:20" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 3, 10, 20</bibl></cit> dub.</sense></entryFree>
mettica: <entryFree id="n28979" type="main" key="metti^ca"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mettĭca</orth> <itype>vitis</itype>, <sense id="n28979.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an unknown species of vine</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:3:2:27" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 3, 2, 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 2, 4, § 35</bibl> (Sillig. Metica).</sense></entryFree>
mettius: <entryFree id="n28980" type="main" key="Metti^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mettĭus</orth>, v. Metius.</entryFree>
mettus: <entryFree id="n28981" type="main" key="Mettus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mettus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Mettĭus</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n28981.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Sabine prænomen</hi>, prob. <hi rend="ital">the title of a magistracy among the Albans</hi> (cf. medix, meddix), e. g. Mettus Curtius, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:23" default="NO" valid="yes">1, 23</bibl> sqq.; v. Metius.</sense></entryFree>
metuens: <entryFree id="n28982" type="main" key="me^tu^ens"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtŭens</orth>, <mood>Part.</mood> and <pos>P. a.</pos>, v. metuo <sense id="n28982.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
metula: <entryFree id="n28983" type="main" key="me_tu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mētŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>meta</etym>, <sense id="n28983.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small pyramid, obelisk</hi> (post-Aug.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:5:6:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 5, 6, 35</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metuo: <entryFree id="n28984" type="main" key="me^tu^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtŭo</orth>, <itype>ŭi, ūtum</itype> (cf.: <sense id="n28984.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">nimis ante metutum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1140" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1140</bibl></cit>), <itype>3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> and <gen>n.</gen> <etym>metus</etym>, <hi rend="ital">to fear, be afraid of</hi> a person or thing; <hi rend="ital">to hesitate, not to venture, not to wish</hi> (syn.: vereor, formido, timeo); with <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>, with <hi rend="ital">ne, to fear lest;</hi> with <hi rend="ital">ui</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ne non, to fear that not;</hi> also of inanimate things, with <hi rend="ital">acc., to fear, revere, reverence</hi> one; as a <hi rend="ital">v. n., to fear, be afraid, be in fear, be apprehensive</hi>, esp. as the effect of the idea of threatening evil (whereas timere usually denotes the effect of some external cause of terror); <hi rend="ital">to dread, apprehend;</hi> with an indirect interrogation: non metuo quin, for non dubito quin, <hi rend="ital">I doubt not but; to be anxious about</hi> any one; with <case>dat.</case> (class.). </sense><sense id="n28984.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Act.</hi>: quem metuont oderunt, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:7:23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 7, 23</bibl> (Trag. v. 403 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">deos et amo et metuo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:2:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 1, 2, 73</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">male ego metuo milvos,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 5, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">metuebant (senem) servi, verebantur liberi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:11:37" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 11, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tu, qui crimen ais te metuisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:30:section=78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 30, § 78</bibl></cit>: nec pol istae metuunt<cb n="METU" />  Deos, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:5:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 5, 2, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">absentem patrem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:1:2:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 1, 2, 68</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec metuit quemquam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:1:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 1, 2, 5</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid a nobis metuit?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 2, 1, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a me insidias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 6, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">supplicia a vobis metuere debent,</quote> <trans><tr>to fear from you</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 3, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a quo (Ajace) sibi non injuriā summum periculum metuebat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 2, 19, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a quo domino sibi metuebat graves cruciatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Lib. Arbitr. 1:4:9" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Lib. Arbitr. 1, 4, 9</bibl></cit>; Gregor. M. Homil. 1, 14, 2; Aug. cont. Acad. 2, 8.—With <hi rend="ital">ex</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si periculum ex illis metuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 52:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 52, 16</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">de</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">de lanificio neminem metuo, una aetate quae sit,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>no one's competition in spinning</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:3:1:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 3, 1, 22</bibl></cit>.—Of inanim. subjects: <cit><quote lang="la">quae res cotidie videntur, minus metuunt furem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:22" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 22</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28984.2" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">metuont credere omnes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:3:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 3, 70</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut tentare spem certaminis metuunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:32:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 32, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nil metuunt jurare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:64:146" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 64, 146</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">reddere soldum,</quote> <trans><tr>not to wish, be averse to</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:5:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 5, 65</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praebere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 18, 1</bibl></cit>.—Of nonpersonal subjects: <cit><quote lang="la">illum aget pennā metuente solvi Fama superstes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 2, 7</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n28984.3" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">ne</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nimis metuebam male, ne abiisses,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:4:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 4, 1, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">male metuo ne ... morbus aggravescat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 3, 2, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fratrem, ne intus sit (Gr. construction),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:3:5:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 3, 5, 62</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28984.4" n="(d)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">ut</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ornamenta, quae locavi, metuo, ut possim recipere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:4:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 4, 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">metuo ut hodie possim emolirier,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:5:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 4, 5, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">metuo ut substet hospes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:5:4:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 5, 4, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut sis vitalis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:1:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 1, 61</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">ne non</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">metuo ne non sit surda,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:3:3:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 3, 3, 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:4:6:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pers. 4, 6, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">metuis ne non, quom velis, convincas esse illum tuom?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:5:3:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 5, 3, 15</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">c</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">quin</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">non metuo meae quin uxori latae suppetiae sient,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:5:1:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 5, 1, 54</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">h</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">object-clause, to await with fear, anxiety; to be in apprehension, concerned about</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">metuo, patres quot fuerint,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:4:3:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 4, 3, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">metui, quid futurum denique esset,</quote> <trans><tr>I dreaded, awaited with fear</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 3, 3, 8</bibl></cit>: metuo quid agam. <hi rend="ital">Sy.</hi> Metuis? quasi non ea potestas sit tua, etc., <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 3, 42</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">metuo qualem tu me esse hominem existumes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:6:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 4, 6, 20</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">q</foreign>) <hi rend="ital">Pass.</hi> with <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam maturis metuendus Juppiter uvis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:419" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 419</bibl></cit>. —（<foreign lang="greek">i</foreign>) <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">se e contempto metuendum fecit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:H. 1:48:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> H. 1, 48, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28984.5" n="B" level="2"> (Eccl. Lat.) Of religious fear, <hi rend="ital">to revere, dread, hold in reverence</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Deum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:25:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Lev. 25, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Dominum Deum nostrum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,049:5:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Jer. 5, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sanctuarium meum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:19:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Lev. 19, 30</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28984.6" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Neutr., to fear, be afraid, be apprehensive</hi>, etc. </sense><sense id="n28984.7" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">de</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque tam de suā vitā, quam de me metuit,</quote> <trans><tr>fears not so much for his own life as for me</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:10:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 10, 4, 6</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28984.8" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">metuens ab Hannibale,</quote> <trans><tr>afraid of Hannibal</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 23, 36</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28984.9" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">pro</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">metuere pro aliquo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 123</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28984.10" n="(d)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">dat., to be anxious about</hi> or <hi rend="ital">for</hi> a person or thing: <cit><quote lang="la">metuens pueris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:5:1:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 5, 1, 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">inopi metuens formica senectae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:186" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 186</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tum decuit metuisse tuis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 10, 94</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtŭens</orth>, <itype>entis</itype>, <hi rend="ital">P. a., fearing, afraid of</hi> any thing; <hi rend="ital">anxious for</hi> any person or thing; with <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> (mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in post-Aug. prose): <cit><quote lang="la">contentus parvo metuensque futuri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:2:110" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 2, 110</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">metuens virgae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:7:210" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 7, 210</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo non metuentius ullum Numinis ingenium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:6:259" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 6, 259</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nero metuentior in posterum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:13:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 13, 25</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
metus: <entryFree id="n28985" type="main" key="me^tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (<sense id="n28985.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fem.</hi>: nulla in me est metus, Enn. ap. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=123" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 123</bibl> Müll.: metus ulla, id. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 214, 11</bibl>; cf. Ann. v. 537, and Trag. v. 179 Vahl.; <case>dat.</case> metu, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 11, 32</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">15, 69</bibl>), <hi rend="ital">fear, dread, apprehension, anxiety;</hi> constr. with <hi rend="ital">gen. object.</hi>, with <hi rend="ital">ne</hi>, with <case>acc.</case> and <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi> </sense><sense id="n28985.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">est metus futurae aegritudinis sollicita exspectatio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:18:52" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 18, 52</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 30, 64</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">metum excitari vel propriis vel communibus periculis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 5, § 505</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in metu esse,</quote> <trans><tr>to be in fear, be fearful</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:7:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 7, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">est et in metu peregrinantium, ut, etc.,</quote> <trans><tr>they are also afraid</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 31, 6, 37, § 71</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mihi etiam unum de malis in metu est, fratris miseri negotium,</quote> <trans><tr>a subject of fear</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:3:9:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 3, 9, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">metum habere,</quote> <trans><tr>to entertain fear, be afraid</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:8:10:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 8, 10, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">metum concipere,</quote> <trans><tr>to become afraid</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:485" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 1, 485</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">capere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:33:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 33, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accipere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:3:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 2, 3, 96</bibl></cit>: metum facere alicui, <hi rend="ital">to make afraid, put in fear, frighten</hi>, Ov. Tr. <pb n="1142" /> <cb n="MEUS" /> 5, 10, 28: <cit><quote lang="la">metum inicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:4:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 4, 19</bibl></cit>: incutere, Cael. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:8:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 8, 4, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">inferre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">affere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:54:section=135" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 54, § 135</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">offerre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:15:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 15, 1, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:4:10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 2, 4, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">intentare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">metu territare,</quote> <trans><tr>to alarm greatly, fill with fear</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">metum pati,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:2:21" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 2, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alicui adimere,</quote> <trans><tr>to take away, remove</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:3:100" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 2, 3, 100</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">metu exonerare,</quote> <trans><tr>to relieve from fear</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">removere metum,</quote> <trans><tr>to take away, remove</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:ib" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">levare alicui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:24:59" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 24, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alicui deicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:49:section=130" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 49, § 130</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">solvere,</quote> <trans><tr>to remove, dismiss</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:463" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 463</bibl></cit>: civitati metum, formidinem oblivionem inicere, Ser. Samm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 3, 9, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">metu et impressione alicujus terroris mentiri,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul.</author> Sent. 5, 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">metu mortis furem occidere, Mos. et Rom. Leg. Coll. 7, 3, 3: quis metus aut pudor est umquam properantis avari?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:14:178" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 14, 178</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">reddere metu, non moribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:13:204" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 13, 204</bibl></cit>.— <usg type="style">Poet.</usg> in <number>plur.</number>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:26:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 26, 1</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n28985.2" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">gen. object.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vulnerum metus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:24:59" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 24, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne reliquos populares metus invaderet parendi sibi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 35:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 35, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">id bellum excitabat metus Pompei victoris Hiempsalem in regnum restituentis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:H. 1:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> H. 1, 39</bibl></cit>; v. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:9:2:14" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 9, 2, 14</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 96</bibl>: propter metum alicujus, <hi rend="ital">for fear of</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Judaeorum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Johan. 7, 13</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">19, 38</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n28985.3" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">ne</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod ubi Romam est nuntiatum, senatui metum injecit, ne, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:7:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 7, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne lassescat fortuna, metus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:130" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 40, 41, § 130</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28985.4" n="(d)" level="5"> With <case>acc.</case> and <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quantus metus est mihi, venire huc salvum nunc patruum!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:3:1:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 3, 1, 18</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">ab</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">metus a praetore Romano,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:24:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 24, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:15:7" default="NO" valid="yes">23, 15, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:33:5" default="NO" valid="yes">25, 33, 5</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">metus poenae a Romanis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:32:23:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 32, 23, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:26:7" default="NO" valid="yes">45, 26, 7</bibl>.—（<foreign lang="greek">z</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">pro</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">metus pro universā republicā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:24:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 24, 4</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">h</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">ex</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">metus ex imperatore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 11, 20</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28985.5" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">religious awe, holy dread</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">laurus Sacra comam multosque metu servata per annos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 60</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Poetic awe</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">evoe! recenti mens trepidat metu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:19:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 19, 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28985.6" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n28985.7" n="A" level="2"> Conor., <hi rend="ital">a cause of fear, a terror</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">metus Libyci,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>the head of Medusa</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:12:606" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 12, 606</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nulli nocte metus,</quote> <trans><tr>alarms</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:3:198" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 3, 198</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28985.8" n="B" level="2"> Personified: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĕtus</orth>, <hi rend="ital">the god of fear</hi> or <hi rend="ital">terror</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:17:44" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 17, 44</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:552" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 552</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:276" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 6, 276</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
metutus: <entryFree id="n28986" type="main" key="me^tu_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕtūtus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood>, from metuo.</entryFree>
meum: <entryFree id="n28987" type="greek" key="me_um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mēum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">mh=on</foreign>, <sense id="n28987.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an umbelliferous plant, bear-wort</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:253" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 20, 23, 94, § 253</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
meus: <entryFree id="n28988" type="greek" key="me^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype> (<case>voc.</case> meus for mi: <sense id="n28988.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">proice tela manu, sanguis meus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:835" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 835</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Lolli meus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 1, 9</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">domine meus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 10</bibl></cit>; <hi rend="ital">gen. plur</hi> meūm for meorum: <cit><quote lang="la">pietas majorum meūm,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:2:6:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 2, 6, 66</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">meapte,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 4, 3, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">meopte,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:2:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 1, 2, 77</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">meāmet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:3:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. 1, 3, 37</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 85:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 85, 24</bibl>; archaic form MIVS: MIEIS MORIBVS, Monum. Scip. in <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 554</bibl>; and mis = meis: ingens cura'st mis concordibus aequiperare, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 955</bibl> P.; cf. Vahl. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0043,001:v. 131, p. 21" default="NO"><author>Enn.</author> Ann. v. 131, p. 21</bibl>), <hi rend="ital">pron. possess</hi>. [me], <hi rend="ital">my, mine, belonging to me, my own</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec ero dicam meo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:304" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 304</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">carnifex,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:1:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 1, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">discriptio,</quote> <trans><tr>made by me</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:17:59" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 17, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">crimen,</quote> <trans><tr>against me, what I am blamed for</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Mag. 10 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl></cit> p. 279: <cit><quote lang="la">non mea est simulatio,</quote> <trans><tr>is not my way</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:5:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 4, 5, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tempestate meā,</quote> <trans><tr>in my day</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:4:140" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 4, 140</bibl></cit>: meus sum, <hi rend="ital">I am myself, in my right senses</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pavidum gelidumque trementi Corpore, vixque meum firmat deus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:689" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 689</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod quidem ego facerem, nisi plane esse vellem meus,</quote> <trans><tr>quite independent</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:7:17" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 2, 7, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vindicta postquam meus a praetore recessi,</quote> <trans><tr>my own master, free</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:5:88" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 5, 88</bibl></cit>: meus est, <hi rend="ital">he is mine, I have him, have caught him, he is in my power</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">meus hic est: hamum vorat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:3:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 3, 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">meus illic homost,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:3:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 2, 3, 63</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:3:147" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 1, 3, 147</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:1:1:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 1, 1, 70</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hic homo meus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:4:7:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 4, 7, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vicimus: en! meus est, exclamat Nāis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:356" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 356</bibl></cit>: meus, <hi rend="ital">my, my own, my dear, my beloved</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nero meus mirificas apud me tibi gratias agit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:64:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 13, 64, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">civis,</quote> <trans><tr>my fellow-citizen</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:12:121" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 12, 121</bibl></cit>.—With apposite <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cui nomen meum absentis honori fuisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:10:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 10, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod meum factum dictumve consulis gravius quam tribuni audistis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:40:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 40, 9</bibl></cit>. ut mea defunctae molliter ossa cubent, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:1:8:108" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 1, 8, 108</bibl>.—<usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕi</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">my friends</hi> or <cb n="MICI" /> <hi rend="ital">relatives, my adherents, my followers</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ego meorum solus sum meus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:4:1:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 4, 1, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">flamma extrema meorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:431" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 431</bibl></cit>: meus homo, or simply meus, i. e. <hi rend="ital">this silly fellow of mine</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">homo meus se in pulpito Totum prosternit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:5:7:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 5, 7, 32</bibl></cit>: at legatus meus ad emendum modo proficiscitur, Auct. Decl. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:18" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">stupor,</quote> <trans><tr>this blockhead of mine</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:17:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 17, 21</bibl></cit>: mea and mea tu, <hi rend="ital">my love, my darling</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mea Pythias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:3:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 4, 3, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mea tu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 3, 1, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">o mea,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:761" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 761</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Voc.</hi>: mi, <hi rend="ital">my dear! my beloved!</hi> o mi Aeschine, o mi germane! <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:2:4:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 2, 4, 4</bibl>.—With the <hi rend="ital">fem.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mi soror,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 5, p. 166, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">4</bibl>, p. 155, 6; <cit><quote lang="la">8, p. 205, 2: mi domina,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> Ep. 22, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mi catella,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mi virgo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 17</bibl></cit>.—In <number>plur.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">mi homines, mi spectatores,</quote> <trans><tr>dear people, good spectators</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:4:2:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cist. 4, 2, 8</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Neutr. absol.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">mĕum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">mine</hi>: quod subrupuisti meum, <hi rend="ital">my property</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">my daughter</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:4:10:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 4, 10, 29</bibl>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">meam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit> v. 14; 26: meum est, <hi rend="ital">it is my affair, my concern, my duty, my custom</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">non est mentiri meum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:2:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 3, 2, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">puto esse meum, quid sentiam, exponere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 6, 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28988.1" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Plur.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fundite quae mea sunt, cuncta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:12:37" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 12, 37</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
mevania: <entryFree id="n28989" type="main" key="Me_va_ni^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mēvānĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n28989.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city in Umbria</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Bevagna</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:41:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 41, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:3:8:3" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 3, 8, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:6:647" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 6, 647</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nebulosa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4</bibl></cit> (5), 1, 123.— Hence, </sense><sense id="n28989.1" n="I" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Mēvānas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <hi rend="ital">comm., of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to the city of Mevania</hi> Mevanas Varenus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:4:546" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 4, 546</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Mēvānā-tes</orth>, <itype>ĭum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Mevania, Mevanians</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:113" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 14, 19, § 113</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n28989.2" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Mē-vānĭensis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj., of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Mevania, Mevanian</hi>: boves, Philar. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:146" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 146</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
mevia: <entryFree id="n28990" type="main" key="Me_vi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mēvĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n28990.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a woman fond of masculine sports</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:1:22" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 1, 22</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
mezentius: <entryFree id="n28991" type="main" key="Mezenti^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mezentĭus</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">Mezzent-, Mesdent-, Messent-, Mēdient-</orth>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Mēdent-</orth>; cf. R<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:in Rhein. Mus. 1857" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> in Rhein. Mus. 1857</bibl>, vol. 12, p. 418 sq.), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n28991.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a male proper name</hi> [of Oscan origin], <hi rend="ital">a tyrant of Cære</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Agylla</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 2</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">Paul. ex Fest. s. v. oscillum, p. 194 Müll.: contemptor divom Mezentius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:648 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 648 sq.</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 3, 5</bibl>; and Serv <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:267" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 267</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">7, 760</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">9, 745</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
mi: <entryFree id="n28992" type="main" key="mi"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mi</orth>. <sense id="n28992.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Dat.</hi> from ego.—</sense><sense id="n28992.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Voc.</hi> from meus; v. h. vv.</sense></entryFree>
mia: <entryFree id="n28993" type="main" key="Mi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĭa Chărĭtōn</orth> = <foreign lang="greek">*xari/twn mi/a</foreign>, <sense id="n28993.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one of the Graces</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:1162" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 1162</bibl>; v. Charites.</sense></entryFree>
mica: <entryFree id="n28994" type="main" key="mi_ca"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mīca</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>root smic-; Gr. <foreign lang="greek">smikro/s</foreign>, <foreign lang="greek">mikro/s</foreign>; cf. micula; O. Germ. smahan, to belittle</etym>, <sense id="n28994.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a crumb, little bit, morsel, grain</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in post-Aug. prose). </sense><sense id="n28994.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">mica panis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">auri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:839" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 839</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">marmoris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 4, 21, § 68</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">salis,</quote> <trans><tr>a grain of salt</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 22, 14, 16, § 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amomi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 12, 18, 41, § 83</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">saliens (i. e. salis) mica,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:23:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 23, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tus in micas friatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 12, 14, 32, § 65</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">de micis puerorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:7:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Marc. 7, 28</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n28994.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n28994.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A small diningroom</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:2:59:1" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 2, 59, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 51:12" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 51, 12</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n28994.4" n="B" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">a little bit, a grain</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nulla in tam magno est corpore mica salis,</quote> <trans><tr>a grain of sense</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:86:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 86, 3</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
micans: <entryFree id="n28995" type="main" key="mi^cans"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĭcans</orth>, <itype>antis</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> and <pos>P. a.</pos>, from mico.</entryFree>
micarius: <entryFree id="n28996" type="main" key="mi_ca_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mīcārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>mica</etym>, <sense id="n28996.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to crumbs</hi> or <hi rend="ital">little bits</hi> (post-Aug.): homo frugi, et micarius, <hi rend="ital">a crumb-gatherer</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">frugal, economical</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 73, 6</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
micatio: <entryFree id="n28997" type="gloss" key="mi^ca_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĭcātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>mico</etym>, <sense id="n28997.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a quick motion</hi>: micatio <foreign lang="greek">laxmo/s</foreign>, Gloss. Philox.</sense></entryFree>
micatus: <entryFree id="n28998" type="main" key="mi^ca_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĭcātus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n28998.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a quick motion</hi> (post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">linguarum micatibus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 4, § 331</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
miccotrogus: <entryFree id="n28999" type="main" key="Miccotro_gus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Miccotrōgus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*mikko/trwgos</foreign>, <sense id="n28999.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the fictitious name of a parasite, Smallbiter</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:1:3:88" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 1, 3, 88</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
miceo: <entryFree id="n29000" type="hapax" key="mice^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">micĕo</orth>, <itype>ēre</itype>, <sense id="n29000.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. n., to bleat</hi>, of a hegoat (al. mutire), Auct. Phil. 58.</sense></entryFree>
michael: <entryFree id="n29001" type="main" key="Micha_e_l"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Michāēl</orth>, <itype>ēlis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, a Hebrew name, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,004:13:14 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Num. 13, 14 al.</bibl>—Esp., <sense id="n29001.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Michael, the archangel</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,056:10:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Dan. 10, 13</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
michaelium: <entryFree id="n29002" type="main" key="Micha^e_li^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Michăēlĭum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*mixa|hlei=on</foreign>, <sense id="n29002.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the church of St. Michael</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cassiod.</author> Hist. Eccl. 2, 19</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
micidus: <entryFree id="n29003" type="hapax" key="mi_ci^dus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mīcĭdus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>mica</etym>, <sense id="n29003.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">thin, poor</hi>, Innocent. Agrar. p. 231 Goes.</sense></entryFree>
micio: <entryFree id="n29004" type="main" key="Micio"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Micio</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n29004.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">name of a man</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:5:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 5, 3, 7</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
micipsa: <entryFree id="n29005" type="main" key="Mi^cipsa"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Mĭcipsa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n29005.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">son of Masinissa, and</hi> <cb n="MICT" /> <hi rend="ital">king of Numidia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 5 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 5 sq.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:3:1" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 3, 1</bibl>. —In <number>plur.</number>, <usg type="style">poet.</usg> for <hi rend="ital">Numidians, Africans</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:5:89" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 5, 89</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
mico: <entryFree id="n29006" type="main" key="mi^co"><orth extent="full" lang="la">mĭco</orth>, <itype>ŭi</itype> (<sense id="n29006.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pf. subj.</hi> micaverit, <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 53</bibl>), <itype>1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <etym>Sanscr. mish-, to wink</etym>, <hi rend="ital">to move quickly to and fro, to have a vibrating</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tremulous motion, to quiver, shake, tremble</hi>, e. g. of the pulse; <hi rend="ital">to beat, palpitate; to spring forth</hi>, of fountains; of the tremulous rays of the stars, <hi rend="ital">to twinkle, sparkle, glitter, gleam, flash</hi> (class.). </sense><sense id="n29006.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">venae et arteriae micare non desinunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:9:24" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 9, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">linguis micat ore trisulcis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:439" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 439</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gladii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:12:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 12, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">corque timore micat,</quote> <trans><tr>beats, palpitates</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:3:36" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 3, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec audissem corde micante tubam,</quote> <trans><tr>for the beating</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:10:12" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 1, 10, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">metu micuere sinus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:1:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 1, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">et modo cervicem, modo crura micantia captat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 9, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">noctuarum genus, quibus pluma aurium modo micat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:29:117" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 29, 6, 38, § 117</bibl></cit>: semianimesque micant (culi (of a head cut off), <hi rend="ital">twitch</hi>, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> Verg.
